title: Radio button
description: Radio buttons allow users to select one option from a set.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Radio buttons are a selection control that often appears when users are asked to make decisions or select a choice from options.
Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline â€“ Radio buttonsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterPlanned
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Use radio buttons to select a single option from a list
  • It should be visible at a glance if a radio button has been selected, and selected items should be more visually prominent than unselected items
  • Present a list showing all available options. If available options can be collapsed, consider using a dropdown menu because it uses less space.
What's new
• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.footer: Radio buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Radio buttons are the recommended way to allow users to make a single selection from a list of options.Â 

Only one radio button can be selected at a time.

contentChunks.footer: Radio buttons should always be be accompanied by clear inline labels.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use radio buttons to:

  • Select a single option from a set
  • Expose all available options

contentChunks.footer: Radio buttons are single-select, unlike checkboxes which are multi-select.
Use radio buttons when only one option can be selected from a list.
Use Checkboxes when multiple options can be selected from a list.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Avoid nesting radio buttons or using radio buttons to select multiple options.

contentChunks.footer: Donâ€™t nest radio buttons.
Donâ€™t allow radio buttons to select multiple options

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Alternate selection controls

Radio buttons are one of several selection controls, which allow users to make choices such as selecting options or switching settings on or off.

Switches and checkboxes are alternative selection controls that can be used to enter decisions or declare preferences such as settings or dialogs.

contentChunks.footer: Switches
Checkboxes

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use radio buttons when there are five or fewer options.

Consider using a drop-down menu instead of radio buttons when itâ€™s important to save space on a screen. However, drop-down menus require additional steps for the user, both in the number of clicks and cognitive effort.

contentChunks.footer: Use radio buttons when there are five or fewer options.
Consider using a drop-down menu instead of radio buttons when space is constrained.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Icon (selected)
2. Adjacent label text
3. Icon (unselected)

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Adjacent label text

Always pair Radio buttons with an adjacent label describing what the radio button selects.

Because only one radio button can be selected at a time, each choice must have its own item and label.

contentChunks.footer: Adjacent label text next to radio buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement
Radio buttons are often arranged in stacked layouts

contentChunks.footer: Stacked list of radio buttons.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Radio buttons should be vertically listed and have one option always selected.

contentChunks.footer: Radio buttons should always have one option pre-selected.
Avoid using horizontal lists, but if your designs requires it, ensure proper spacing between list items.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

A radio button is successfully selected

when the user has clicked or tapped either the radio button icon or the label.

contentChunks.footer: Radio button behavior.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use cases

Users should be able toÂ 

  • Navigate to a radio button list item with assistive technology
  • Select radio button
  • Get appropriate feedback based on input type documented under Interaction & style

Interaction & style

The radio button has two states: selected and unselected. Thereâ€™s a brief but important interaction where the user changes the states of the buttons by selecting an option.

Users should be able to select either the text label or the radio button to select an option. Once selected, there is always one radio button selected in the group, users can change their selection but they canâ€™t unselect.

Initial focus

When in groups: TAB moves focus into â€¨the groupâ€™s selected radio, the first radio if none are selected, or the last radio with SHIFT-TAB.

contentChunks.footer: Tab brings the focus to the initially selected item or the initial radio option
Arrows move to next element in list

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TABTo move to the next element in a group
SHIFT-TABTo select the last radio button item in a group
ARROWSTo move up or down, between radio options and make a selection
SPACETo select a focused radio option not yet selected

Labeling elements

If the UI text is correctly linked to the radio button, assistive tech (such as a screenreader) will read the UI text followed by the componentâ€™s role.

The accessibility label for a group of radio buttons is â€œradio group.â€
The accessibility label for an individual radio button is typically the same as its adjacent text label.
